episode.title: Immigration and Naturalization Service v. Yueh-Shaio Yang

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 95-938, Immigration & Naturalization Service v. Yueh-Shaio Yang.
Ms. Brinkmann, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
This case involves respondent's request for a waiver of deportation under section 241(a)(1)(H) of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
The act commits that decision to the discretion of the Attorney General.

Exercising her discretion in this case, the Attorney General properly considered numerous frauds committed by respondent, including his fraudulent application for naturalization, fraudulent marriages, fraudulent divorce, and his participation in the fraudulent obtaining of documents for his wife's fraudulent entry into the country.
The Attorney General did not, again as a matter of discretion, consider the fraud respondent committed at entry.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I take it under the statute, the Attorney General would have been perfectly free to consider that fraud.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, and in fact the Seventh Circuit has expressly recognized that.

In Rodriguez-Barajas, Judge Easterbrook explained that the Attorney General's under no compulsion to disregard that initial fraud, and that any limitation on that has arisen out of the Attorney General's exercise of her discretion.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, you think, then, that the statute places no outer limits whatever on the discretion of the Attorney General?
If the Attorney General took the position that the fact of a fraudulent entry by the alien is a factor weighing against waiver, then nobody would be entitled to a waiver any time.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Well, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I mean, that condition exists in every one of these cases.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.
The aliens that are in the pool of eligible aliens for this type of waiver share several common characteristics.
They all have three factors weighing in their favor.
They have to be the relative... the parent, son or daughter or spouse of a citizen or a permanent resident alien.
They also must have presented themselves for entry.
They have to have a validly, facially valid document, and they have to be otherwise admissible.
They also share the fact--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But for the fraud.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Yes.
They also share the fact that they all committed entry fraud.

Now, looking at that pool of applicants, the Attorney General has to decide who amongst that she should exercise her discretion to give a waiver to, and our submission is that it's certainly proper for the Attorney General to favor a person who has been law-abiding since their initial entry over someone who's perpetrated a series of frauds.

We would also submit, Your Honor, although it has not come up in the typical kinds of cases that have come before the board, if, for example, the entry fraud was intertwined with violence, for example, we certainly think the Attorney General in her discretion could take that into account.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, could take into account the circumstances of the particular fraudulent entry.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But not the mere fact that there had been a fraudulent entry, I take it?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: I'd look to the... for example, the Court in the Rios-Pineda case, when the Court was looking at the Attorney General's authority whether or not to grant suspension of deportation there, I think characterizes looking to the nature and severity of the factor, so I would think that that would clearly be appropriate for the Attorney General to take into account.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, just because Congress has given the Attorney General the power to waive fraud, certainly you don't concede that the Attorney General couldn't say, I have the power but I decline to waive any kind of fraud.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

In fact, particularly in the immigration context there may be other matters of foreign affairs or international relations that at a particular point in time the Attorney General would choose not to exercise her discretion in favor of waivers under this provision.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The statute does circumscribe discretion in one respect, does it not, or perhaps not, because the sentence is difficult.
The last sentence of sub (H), a waiver of deportation for fraud granted under this subparagraph shall also operate to waive deportation based on the grounds of inadmissibility at entry.
What's the function of that sentence, other than to circumscribe or control the discretion of the AG?
Maybe you'll tell me--

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: If I under--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --it's an interpretation of the discretion once exercised.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I think, if I understand your question correctly, Your Honor, it's clarifying some confusion that had existed under their previous provision, and it makes clear that if the Attorney General grants a waiver of deportation under this provision, that waiver of deportation waived the grounds of inadmissibility for the fraud and also for inadmissibility grounds that directly result from that, that being a fraudulent visa or fraudulent labor certification.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would that be relevant in a later application for citizenship, or something like that?
Is that why it's important?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Well, in fact--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Because it seems to me to just restate that a waiver's a waiver.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, I think I can give an example to explain it.
There is some fraud at entry that doesn't involve fraudulent documents or labor certificates.
Misrepresenting your marital status, perhaps, in an interview.

Some people obtain their visas based on false information at a consulate beforehand, and then when they arrive at the port of entry, they continue to stand by what's in that visa, but perhaps they've been unmarried... they've been divorced or married in the meantime, so they would be committing a fraud at entry, but that would not necessarily relate to any fraudulent document.

If they had an independently based fraudulent document, that could be a ground of inadmissibility, and it would not be waived because it would not directly result from their fraud, and I think what the statute was trying to get at was that any of the grounds of inadmissibility at the time of entry that directly result from the entry fraud are also waived.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: May I--
--But then that is a narrowing of the Attorney General's discretion.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No.
We would simply say that describes what the effect of the grant of the waiver is.
The Attorney General grants a waiver, and it specifies that it waives deportation based on those grounds.
That's what the effect of a 241(a)(1)(H) waiver--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, it circumscribes the Attorney General to some extent in that it does control the extent of the waiver.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --The effect of it, yes, Your Honor.

On the other hand, we would submit that as in my previous discussion of how the Attorney General could take into account the nature and severity of the initial fraud, the Attorney General certainly also as matter of discretion could take into account the nature and severity of the other grounds of inadmissibility on the fraudulent labor certificate or visa, the means by which that was procured.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I have to confess I'm still a little puzzled about your answer to Justice O'Connor.

I understood you to say that the Attorney General could not take into account the mere existence of some fraud, could take into account the nature of the fraud, but are you saying that if... say there's the mildest kind of form in the... fraud in the world, that the mere fact there was a fraud could not be taken into consideration?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, I'm sorry, I misspoke if I--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No matter how mild it is, the Attorney General has discretion.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --That's--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Otherwise, it seems to me a person could commit a fraud and then claim a right to remain.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --That's right, and in fact, Your Honor, one of the ironies of the Ninth Circuit's ruling in this case is, it really gives the type of open-ended immunity to aliens who enter by fraud.

By requiring that later frauds be considered as a part of or an extension of the entry fraud, those aliens are put at an advantage over an alien who enters lawfully and then commits later fraud which is not forgiven.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But are you saying that the Attorney General would be within her discretion to say, I will never exercise my discretion to waive entry fraud?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: We believe that if that were based on a reasonable exercise of her discretion--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but that begs the question.
The only fact you know is that she says, I'm adopting a policy.
I will never exercise discretion, no matter what the circumstances, to waive entry fraud.
Would that be lawful or not?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, we believe it would be.

I guess in my initial answer I was trying to think of an example in which that might be the case, and I come back to the example of perhaps there are other immigration interests and other quotas that are so... so important, and as a matter of policy--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but my question suggested that that was her across-the-board policy for all cases in which the statute might be applied.
I'm not asking a question about subclasses.
I'm talking about the entire class of possible waivers, and construed that broadly, would it be within her discretion to say, I will never exercise my discretion in favor of waiver?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --You mean waivers under 241(a)(1)(H)?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, we believe it would be.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But in any event, the BIA has adopted a different standard, right?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And unless that standard is changed, I assume the Government would abide by the standard--

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --that's been adopted.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's correct, and it's a reasonable approach.

I think the board has found that the cases that have come before it, that entry fraud does seem to be of a common ilk, and has decided to treat like cases alike in that regard, and need not look at that initial factor.

As I mentioned earlier, if a case arose in which a different type of entry fraud was involved involving violence, for example, we believe that would be certainly something which the board may very well--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But do you say you're free to depart from that rule and that practice at any time you want?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, I think to the extent that--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: For no reason at all?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I think to the extent that there is judicial review for abuse of discretion the board would be well advised to provide a reason.

I have to hasten... have to... have to be quick to add at this point, Your Honor, at this point it's somewhat of a limited query, because the new statute that was passed a week and a half ago eliminates judicial review of the Attorney General's exercise of discretion under this provision.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But currently, do I understand it correct... I must say, I was quite surprised to discover this, but the situation is, if you commit entry fraud and are successful, so long as you don't commit any other fraud, you're okay.
Is that the current position?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: You're eligible for a waiver.
That doesn't mean you get it, Your Honor.
At that point you can apply to the Attorney General.
You have to be a relative--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you may not get it, but you won't be denied it simply because you got in fraudulently.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --It will... when the Attorney General, the Board of Immigration Appeals, the immigration judge exercise their discretion, the practice at this point is not to take into account the initial entry fraud.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I find that extraordinary, myself.
No matter how severe--
--I'm sorry.
Why is that?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: The fact of the matter is, Your Honors, when I've looked through all the cases, the typical case that has come forward involves very similar types of fraud, mainly people misrepresenting the fact they've been married, or been divorced, family relations.
There have not been cases which involve incidences of violence, for example, and--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, why is it that in those kinds of cases... why does the BIA disregard that fraud?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Well, to an extent, Your Honor, I think that it's taken as a matter of treating like cases alike, and that that's--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you could treat like cases alike and say we'll... we will not disregard it in any of them.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Right, and that's what the alien's coming forward to, as asking for forgiveness for, as the board has characterized it.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Brinkmann, there was one time when this kind of waiver for initial entry fraud was mandatory.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And then it was urged that Congress drop it altogether.
Instead, Congress came up with something in between.

They said the entry by fraud may, in the discretion of the Attorney General, be waived, but if you can respond to the question that's been raised by several of the justices, why in the first place did Congress provide for initially a mandatory waiver and now a discretionary waiver for one who has gained entry by fraud?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Your Honor, initially, this was enacted as section 7 of the Immigration Act in 1957, and it was responding to entry by... immigrants were fleeing repression in totalitarian regimes, and had made misrepresentations in order to avoid repression, and that's when the provision was first enacted, added to the statute.
Then it was somewhat modified in 1961.

In between 1961 and 1981, that's when all the trouble and confusion started occurring, and that's what prompted Congress in 1981, or the proposals pending in Congress, to eliminate it altogether because it had caused such confusion.
For example, persons who entered by an innocent misrepresentation some courts had held were not eligible for the waiver, whereas aliens who had entered through fraudulent misrepresentations were.
That's something that the 1981 statute... amendment corrected.
It also, of course, made it discretionary.
It also made it clear, for example, that it was not going to waive deportation for aliens who entered without inspection.
Now--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --policy by discretion of the executive is that anyone who commits fraud successfully upon entry is okay.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I wouldn't say it's okay, Your Honor, but it's enough like all of the other cases that have come before the board that it's a wash, and that the board look, and the immigration judges look at the other factors that underlie the interest in the stat... this provision--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You get in under the provision of the law that says a spouse can get in, and you lie.
You say I'm married to somebody.
You are in fact not married to somebody.
So long as you persuade the officer of the truth of that lie, it's okay.
Once you're in, it's all right.
That's the policy we now have in place.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Right.
Well, it dates back to 1978, Your Honor.
There's a similar provision for waiver of exclusion grounds, and that's when the Commissioner of INS first articulated this.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I thought we were going to get serious about... about enforcing our borders, and I was really quite surprised to find that that's the policy.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I have to say I think that in light of the statute that was recently passed, that Your Honor... certainly it's a situation I think now where Congress has eliminated this provision from judicial review, and the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that doesn't save anything.
The Attorney General can continue to let everybody in who's lied successfully, and there's no judicial review.
It may make it worse.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I would hasten to add, Your Honor, I mean, this waiver of deportation does apply to a limited pool of people.

It applies to people who are immediate relatives of U.S. citizens, or permanent resident aliens, and the main thrust behind this provision was for family unification, as I initially pointed out to Justice Ginsburg, in '57, it had to do with the nature of countries that aliens were fleeing, but the real interest--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do they have to now be an immediate relative?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, suppose they lied when they came in and they said they were an immediate relative.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: They have to be one.
That's a statutory eligibility--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They have to be one now.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --At the time of the application for the waiver and the grant of the waiver, yes, Your Honor, and that was really the interest underlying, so although I think at first blush it may sound frivolous to permit people who have lied or misrepresented, I think that Congress really envisioned an overriding interest in the unification of families.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your position here, I take it, Ms. Brinkmann, is that although the Attorney General has exercised her discretion in this manner to forgive entry fraud, that she has control of just what that means, and it shouldn't be expanded by the courts.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but on the other hand, I take it that you're saying that what the Attorney General's position has been, which is to overlook the initial fraud, is suggested if not compelled by the statutory history.
Isn't that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: We don't believe that it is compelled by that, Your Honor, no.
We think that to the extent the Ninth Circuit authority can be read that way, they're clearly wrong.
We agree with Judge Easterbrook's opinion in the Seventh Circuit, which states that their statute imposes no compulsion on the Attorney General to disregard that initial fraud.
That simply is one of the eligibility requirements.
That's one of the factors I described earlier that all the aliens in the applicant pool have in common.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, that would make a lot of sense to me but for the way the Attorney General has administered the statute to date.
I can't understand where it gets... where that policy derives from, and I thought your earlier remarks indicated it derived from the statutory history.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, I think it actually derives from the history before the agency itself, Your Honor.
As I explained, it actually piggybacks on an interpretation of waiver for exclusion under section 212(i) in 1978.
The Commissioner of the INS set forth this policy and that's what eventually was incorporated into the Attorney General's interpretation of the deportation waiver.
When that first statement was made about the exclusion waiver, the deportation waiver was not yet discretionary.
It was mandatory.

The exclusion waiver has always been discretionary, so once the deportation waiver became discretionary in 1981, and the Attorney General came to start interpreting that, she looked back to the interpretation that had been given to the exclusion waiver that was always discretionary.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Am I right, I thought... I might not be, but I... my reading of this was initially there were a group of people who did lie when they wanted to come in, particularly people who came from Iron Curtain countries, and they lied about what country they were coming from because they were afraid that they'd be sent back and killed possibly, and Congress initially passed this statute because it wanted to say that people like that who had families here should be permitted to stay here.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And if that's so, then wouldn't it raise a legal question if the Attorney General said people just like that, or who tell equivalent lies to that, would all have to go back?

That's why I wonder if there isn't some limitation arising out of the circumstances in this, where the history of this, that there were certain lies that would be told and the need to reunite families was such that that would be a limitation on the AG's discretion.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: We don't believe so, Your Honor.
I think looking at the text of this statute following the 1981 amendment, Congress was clear to write that the deportation may be waived in the discretion of the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Regardless of the history, what the statute does is give the Attorney General discretion.
That's what it says.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.
I think particularly against the backdrop of the history in 1981, where there had been proposals to eliminate it altogether.

Also, I would add, Congress did set out the statutory eligibility requirements we've already discussed, and did not include any other even factors to consider in many provisions of the Immigration Nationality Act.
For example, Congress has told the Attorney General specifically to consider hardship to family members and all that.
This waiver provision contains none of that, and we think that bolsters our interpretation that it's left to the sole discretion of the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Ms. Brinkmann, may I go to the other end of the spectrum and make sure I understand you on one point, and that is, I understand you to have said that the policy of waiving any initial fraud applies to any initial fraud regardless of what it's circumstances may be.
In other words, there's no minor fraud versus major fraud.
All frauds are equal if they are initial fraud, initial entry frauds, is that right?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: It's difficult to answer that question, Your Honor, because the cases all have very comparable types of fraud.
There just haven't been--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right, what if you had a fraud case in which you... it was shown that the documents were procured by the entrant by holding a gun to the head of officials in foreign countries to force them to produce the fraudulent documents, would that be like all other kinds of frauds?
Would that be within the policy of waiving all initial entry frauds?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I think that would be within... it would be within the discretion of the Attorney General, her delegates, to decide.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but I want to know what her policy... I just want to understand what her policy is now, and would that fall within her policy of waiving initial entry fraud as you understand it?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That case simply has not come up, Your Honor, and I would not want to say that it would come within that, because I think that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So maybe not all frauds are equal for... initial entry frauds are equal.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --They may not be, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: I think that's true, and I think the Attorney General would be free to change her policy and explain that in the future any entry frauds that have to do with violence certainly are going to be weighed much more severely, in fact--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that limitation doesn't exist right now.
As far as we know now, and this is what I got from the brief, all entry fraud is not taken into account.
Isn't that the rule as it now exists?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Frankly, Your Honor, we also don't know the other way, because the case just has not arisen, and the Attorney General has not been presented with that situation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You don't know of a single case of entry fraud that has been taken into account.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, Your Honor, certainly not in the reported cases I've seen.
It might be, Your Honor, because in situations like that, the alien is more than likely going to be not otherwise admissible, will be inadmissible on other grounds.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And there's also a question of what is the entry fraud.

If I understand the way this policy operates, in this case there was a sham divorce in Taiwan before the petitioner entered, and you count that as preentry fraud, so if I understand what the policy is correctly, all of the other... the later frauds postentry were just kind of surplus.
It was enough to be outside this policy that there was a preentry fraud.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Your Honor, these are certainly I think a totality of circumstances when the Attorney General exercises her discretion, and any type of misdeed--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, I wasn't asking you that.

I may understand her policy incorrectly, but I thought your explanation of the policy was, we will waive entry fraud but nothing before and nothing after, and here there was a before, and now you're saying no, I don't have it right, it's somehow a totality of the circumstances test and not, we'll zero in on the entry itself, I get there and say I'm from... I'm from Austria rather than from Poland.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor, I misunderstood.
I wanted to say that the... some misdeed beforehand can certainly be considered.
I just did not want to say that that was dispositive and meant that a waiver could not be granted.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I must say, I don't understand this concept of preentry fraud.
Who is the fraud being committed on?
I mean--

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: On the United--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --States, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But it's only being committed on the United States at the time you present yourself for entry.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, surely I can enter into a sham divorce if I want, and until such time as I applied for entry to the United States, it doesn't make any difference to the United States.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Your Honor, respondent collaborated in obtaining fraudulent birth certificates and passports for his wife, and the reason that the divorce and remarriage under an assumed name that he also participated in was to commit a fraud in the United States of America as his wife coming in under the fraud of being a U.S. citizen.
If he had never come to this country--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It was her wife's entry that was the fraud.
It wasn't the--
--His wife's.
I mean, it was the wife's entry that he assisted that was fraud.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --That's true, and he--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Yes.
I also wanted to point out that respondent in the court of appeals agreed with this view and admitted that the naturalization fraud, for example, its fraudulent application could be weighed, and--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There was a fraudulent application for citizenship here too, wasn't there?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I'm sorry, that's what I meant, Your Honor.
I misspoke.
Yes, in 1982.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the Ninth Circuit said that was improperly considered by the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You advised Justice Scalia that this was a very small class.
I would have thought that numerically it's quite significant.
Do you have any specific numbers as to how small this class is?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: I actually do have some statistics from the... from fiscal year '95, Your Honor.
I've been informed by... this is from the Executive Office of Immigration Review.

These were decisions on... they classified them as 241(f) waivers, but it's now at 241 (a)(1)(H), and last year there were a total of 30... this was for immigration judge rulings, 37 waivers with a grant rate of approximately 84 percent.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Brinkmann.
I take it you want to reserve--

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: I'd like to reserve the rest of my time.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Mr. Hom.
Am I pronouncing your name correctly?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
There are two basic points that we need to address.
Number 1, this case, the facts of this case boils down to just one simple fact.
Mr. Yang's assumed identity as the husband of a United States citizen, just one basic fact.
Secondly, this is not a case of abuse of discretion.
This is a case of statutory construction.

This is a case of statutory construction because the plain language of the statute, the INS's own interpretation, prior case precedents, legislative history, and the policy and the purpose behind this waiver all indicate that the original fraud must never be weighed in the decision to grant or deny a waiver.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: As a matter of... you say part of your argument to that effect is based on statutory construction.
Where in the statute do you find that?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Yes, it's subparagraph (ii) of 241(a)(1)(H), and the petitioner's brief at page 5a and 6a is the section of law, and in subparagraph (ii) on page 6a it states that the alien was in possession of an immigrant visa or equivalent document and was otherwise admissible, and that's the key phrase, otherwise admissible.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well--
--Why isn't the key phrase,
"fraud may, in the discretion of the Attorney General, be waived? "
Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Because the purpose of the waiver was to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We're talking about statutory construction now.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Oh, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Right.
The waiver serves to take away that fraud.
That's why that phrase, "otherwise admissible", that's what that refers to.
Otherwise, other than the fraud.
Otherwise admissible means other than the fraud that charges or that renders the alien to become excludable.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, that sets a condition upon the--
--Yes.
--exercise of discretion... but it does not, it seems to me, to address the substance of what that discretion may consider.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: If I could answer the question this way, Your Honor, there are three steps in the processing of an application for a waiver before the immigration judge.
The first step is, is there a requisite family relationship, the second step, subparagraph (ii), is the alien otherwise admissible?
In other words, is he a criminal?
Has he committed other heinous acts but he cannot be neither waivered because of the fraud, which is 212(a)(6)(C), and that's what otherwise admissible refers to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, why do you... that isn't at all clear to me.

I mean, why isn't the otherwise... just a threshold requirement, and once you meet that threshold, then you can invoke the Attorney General's discretion, but the statute doesn't say how it should be exercised.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

Once we reach that threshold that the fraud is taken off the table and not to be considered in order for the alien to apply for the waiver, then for the Immigration Service to turn around and look at that very same act would really nullify subparagraph (ii).
It wouldn't even have to be there at all if the Attorney General had absolute unfettered discretion.
The language of the waiver would merely say, if the alien has a family relationship, then in the discretion of the Attorney General the waiver may be granted, so there must be some meaning--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So you say the fact that Congress has imposed additional conditions over and above the family relationships actually limits the Attorney General's discretion.
That seems rather strange.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --And that's why I say, it's not a matter of discretion, Your Honor, it's really a matter of statutory construction.
Subparagraph (ii) takes--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But construing the statute, mustn't we take into account first the words that say
"may, in the discretion of the Attorney General. "
then the history that at one time the waiver was mandatory, and Congress changed it to make it discretionary.
You seem to be... your statutory interpretation argument appears to be based on the pre-1981 statute, when the waiver was mandatory.
Are you saying that Congress... that these words are meaningless?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Your Honor, the change to add the word discretion in 1981 did not change the intent and purpose of the waiver.

Even prior to the 1981 waiver change there was a separate exclusion ground with a parallel waiver, section 212(i), which permitted the Immigration Service to grant a waiver in its discretion for similar types of frauds.

The Immigration Service adopted the position in the parallel deportation waiver in now 241(a)(1)(H) that otherwise admissible means you put aside the initial fraud that renders him excludable in deciding whether or not to grant the waiver, and then the immigration judge, or the Immigration Service, may look at other adverse factors.

For example, if the immigrant had killed somebody to obtain that person's passport, or visa documentation, that would render the immigrant excludable under other acts, sections of the act, so that's the purpose of otherwise admissible, to account for the concern that Your Honors have expressed previously that there may be certain factors in the commission of the fraud that are so heinous that we as human beings would not accept.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, so then you're saying otherwise admissible is not important to your interpretation of the act because you've given it this other meaning.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: I'm not sure if that's--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's what your whole... I thought your whole case turned on the otherwise admissible language, and you've just given what to me is a very plausible interpretation of it that the man can't be a heinous criminal, et cetera.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Correct, so--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I don't see how that helps your case.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Well, we're saying that if the alien is... in the determination of the waiver we look at other factors other than the fraud factor, which is 212(a)(6)(C), which is not listed there, but you could see the parallel exceptions for (5)(A) and (7)(A) of the statute, so if an alien is encompassed within the grounds of 212(a)(6)(C), 212(a)(5)(A) and (7)(A), those disqualifying factors cannot be held against the immigrant in the determination of the waiver, so the immigration judge is permitted only to look at other factors, other than those three factors.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If that's so, I can understand... just... how you could say may means must in respect to the initial kinds of fraud that led Congress to grant the discretion in the first place, which is what you're arguing now, I think, but assuming for the sake of argument that that's so, how then do you get from the language which talks about a waiver being related... being a direct result of that fraud... it says, that fraud, and that fraud means the fraud that enabled the alien to procure a visa, which this alien procured in 1978.

How do you get from that to saying that the Attorney General cannot take into account her view of a different fraud, i.e., one that happened in 1982 that led to the procurement of naturalization papers?
Even if you're going to say they're all part and parcel of the same thing, I don't see how you escape the language.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: If we look at the initial language of 241(a)(1)(H) on page 5a, the provisions of this paragraph relating to the deportation of aliens within the United States on the ground that they were excludable at the time of entry as aliens, described in section 1182(6)(C).

So if you look at the classification described in 212(a)(6)(C), which is on the petitioner's brief at page 2a, the language there states... misrepresentation is the caption... any alien who by fraud or wilfully misrepresenting a material fact seeks to procure or has sought to procure or has procured a visa or other documentation or entry into the United States, those words there clearly show that acts could have occurred not just at the time of entry, but in the past in seeking the visa, or actually having obtained the visa, so it's very clear that the statute that grants the waiver is not limited to acts occurring at the time of entry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's not the statute that grants the waiver, it's the statute that makes the immigrant eligible to request a waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.
Right.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: And the historical development of the act... of the waiver--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's still referring to the fraud that led him to have procured the visa.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Well, that's not inconsistent with 212(a)(6)(C).
The statutory language talks and uses words in terms of present tense and past tense, so that those acts which are related to the visa procurement, yes.

If there are other acts not related to the visa procurement, then he would be otherwise inadmissible and the waiver could be denied, so I don't see that as inconsistent with our position, and I think that that should lay to rest a lot of concerns that the waiver is carte blanche to let immigrants come in, commit heinous crimes, and get away with murder.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Hom, if we looked at it from this point of view, let's say that there's something ambiguous about this, and a judge is trying to determine what the statute means and says, well... let's assume that one person who got into the United States without making any false representations, no fraud, and once in the United States engaged in the very same acts as occurred here, such a person would be deportable, but if in addition to engaging in those acts there had been a fraud at entry, that person is eligible for a waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is that a reasonable way to--

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --to construe what Congress did?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
The waiver that is being... the fraud that is being waived is the fraud to come to the United States.
Frauds that are unrelated that occur afterwards... tax fraud, welfare fraud... all those are separate, independent acts which render the immigrant deportable under different sections of 241(a).

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What about the 1982 fraud here, the citizenship?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Citizenship, on the application Mr. Yang repeated the same statements, that his wife is Mary Wong--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But he repeated them 4 years later, didn't he?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

This is a case of an assumed identity, where the immigrant comes to the United States with a new identity as the husband of Mary Wong, and everything that he does after that is as the husband of Mary Wong.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, he's just continuing to make fraudulent representations, then.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: He repeats the same statement, Your Honor, that he is the husband--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but, you know, I can repeat the same statements to defraud people time after time.
That doesn't mean that all are subsumed under the first one.
Each repetition is a new fraudulent representation.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, the... the INS has always interpreted the waiver to waive the conditions of the fraud, and until this case there has never been a slicing up of the fraud into subcomponents.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but the INS didn't interpret it this way in this case.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So I mean, this was not the Attorney General's view.
This was the view, the Ninth Circuit said the Attorney General has to do this.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --The Ninth Circuit looks at Mr. Yang's assumed identity as one fraud rather than individual acts.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And why... where did they get the authority to do that, when the discretion resides in the Attorney General, not the Ninth Circuit?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Correct, but the statutory language and the intent of Congress in passing the waiver was to not only help displaced refugees, but there's a subsection that granted the waiver to people with family relations who may not have--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It didn't grant the waiver.
I think--

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Excuse me.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --It... they could have the threshold, and then the Attorney General may grant the waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's correct, and if... after the threshold is made, the Attorney General looks at other factors other than the fraud, because that is the act for which he is being forgiven for.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But surely the Attorney General can look at a fraud that was committed 4 years after entry.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: But the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Can the Attorney General look at a fraud that was committed 4 years after entry?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Only if it is not related to the initial entry.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, where do you get that from?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: The concept of the fraud that exists at the time of entry.
This is the same fraud that exists at the time of entry.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, it's the same fraudulent statement, but it's repeated 4 years later.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: And for the same purpose of his immigration status.
It's not to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It wasn't to obtain entry, it was to obtain citizenship, so it isn't the same purpose.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Every immigrant, Your Honor, comes to America for the purpose of settling here permanently, and citizenship is the ultimate, is the final step in his process in coming to the United States.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Even on your theory of relationship, how do you relate the misrepresentation about the financial status?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Well, that was a matter that the court of appeals remanded back to the immigration judge for redetermination.
Cases have held that false statements to the immigration judge are properly considered in the exercise of discretion.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And you agree with that?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: The general rule that false statements to the judge--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You agree with that?
You do not contest that general rule?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Statements to the judge, correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Hom, could you help me with the statute here?
I have trouble reading it.

It's on page 5a and 6a of the Government's brief, and the crucial provision, the subsection (ii), Roman (ii), reads, was in possession of an immigrant visa or equivalent document and was otherwise admissible to the United States at the time of such entry except for those grounds of inadmissibility specified under paragraphs (5)(A) and (7)(A), and 1182(a) of this title, which were a direct result of that fraud or misrepresentation... what is that?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That requires an antecedent, and I scanned this statute for any prior reference to fraud or misrepresentation, and I can't find any.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Yes, what that refers to, Your Honor, is that if the immigrant had applied... you have two situations.

The immigrant applies for his immigrant visa based upon a labor certification, for example, and he... if he properly processed that labor certification, but submitted fraudulent documents, then that is the kind of fraud that directs... directly results from that act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you say it should read, except for those grounds of inadmissibility specified under paragraphs (5)(A) and (7)(A) which required labor certification.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And section 1182, which is requirement of a visa.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Except for those grounds... let's see, which involved fraud or misrepresentation and were a direct result thereof, is how it should have read.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: I'd like to... I think I hear what Your Honor's saying--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: My problem is the word that, a direct result of that.
What fraud or misrepresentation?
There's no fraud or misrepresentation mentioned.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Isn't it right that that's in (6)(C)?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Correct.
That's--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And the reason that it's in (6)(C)... the reason that it's in (6)(C), as I read it, is in the preceding codification the words fraud and representation were at the top of (f), and they were broken out by Congress and moved to (6)(C), and so the antecedent for that is now (6)(C), is that right?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Thank you, Your Honor, but there's also one other aspect of that.
If an immigrant had bought the visa outside of the consular context instead of in the process of applying for an immigration visa--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But is what I said right?
I don't want you to agree if it's not right.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Oh, that's correct, but there's another aspect to it.
There are two explanations.

I was... that's one, and the second one is, where the fraudulent documentation, say the fake passport was a counterfeit that he'd purchased down the street, so it was not part of a fraud to the United States Government.

As Your Honor had pointed out earlier, if he had divorced his wife and had not made that representation or showed that divorce document to the consular officer at his visa interview, then that would not be the kind of fraud that's encompassed and would not be the kind of fraud that would be forgiven by this waiver, so this is not a charter of amnesty.
There are cases of frauds and bad acts that may be punished, and properly so.

There are criminal sanctions that would be available, and once criminal convictions are obtained, then the alien becomes inadmissible under various sections of 212(a), so that the integrity of the immigration system is preserved.
There are not a whole lot of waivers granted under this particular section.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Hom, there's one problem that I have with your notion that the consistent repetition of the same misrepresentation is a wash.
As long as you say the same thing every time, then it all must be forgiven.
The statements about Mary Wong who was a dead soul, that were repeatedly made on documents signed by these people, were they not indictable crimes as false statements made to the United States?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Possibly, but that's the very waiver that is... the reason why the waiver is there.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So what you're saying is that you could have these people engage in repeated criminal conduct and nonetheless the Attorney General must ignore that in determining their eligibility for a waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Yes, if the fraudulent conduct relates back to the initial one.
The appropriate solution--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So if there is any ambiguity you say yes, we should interpret Congress to mean that people who have committed in the United States repeated criminal acts nonetheless must be eligible for this waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Incorrect.
The key phrase was eligible for the waiver.
Subparagraph (ii) specifically states that if--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's what I said, eligible for the waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Right, but he would not be eligible for the waiver because he would have been convicted of crimes involving moral turpitude, which are other grounds enumerated in subparagraph (ii) which are not listed there, but that's what the reference--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So what you say is, although this conduct, signing a false statement, could be indicted, if it's not indicted, it must be treated as if it didn't happen.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Not necessarily indicted.
If there are... if there's an admission that he had committed the elements of the act that involves--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is there... is... are you denying that Mr. Yang signed papers and presented them to immigration officials saying that he was the husband of Mary Wong, a citizen of the United States?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --He did sign those documents, and that's the purpose of the waiver.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And was it not true that at the time he signed those documents Mary Wong was a very dead soul?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's correct.
His wife, Mr. Yang's wife had assumed the identity of Mary Wong.
He did not represent that he was married to a deceased person.

He was saying that his wife, his current wife, who used a new name, and that's why I've been trying to explain that this is a matter of an assumed identity as opposed to a... another type of elaborate fraud, as Your Honors have eluded to.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, it seems to me extraordinary that Congress would mandate that the Attorney General not consider what is concededly repeated crimes of false statements to the United States Government.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, in this case there was one immigration examiner who was indicted and convicted for having received bribes, or soliciting bribes in this respect, and that's in the brief.
If there was criminal acts that could be charged against Mr. Yang, I'm pretty sure that the FBI would have ferreted out those facts--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, I've just asked you, did he sign a document in which he said he was the husband of Mary Wong?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Yes, he did, but--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And he could not have been the husband of Mary Wong, as Mary Wong was dead.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

If there was evidence to lead to a criminal conviction, one should have been brought, and then he should have been convicted and, if convicted, deported on that basis, and not deported based upon some exception or some misconstruction of a statute that has very salutary purposes behind it just because of potential prosecution.

If there was a prosecution, then he renders himself not to be otherwise admissible within the language of subparagraph (ii) and the person could be deported, so it's not a matter of denying the waiver.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But something he does 4 years afterwards, that wouldn't bear on his admissibility, would it?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: The waiver focuses on two points.

Number 1, at the time of entry, is he within this classification of having committed this fraud, so he commits this one particular fraud, and he's warranted with it and it becomes an individual part of his new identity... there's just no way he could shake that.
So when the person applies for his social security card he puts down on the form he's married.
When he applies for... when he submits his income tax returns he says he's married, and I'm sure he put down he was married to Mary Wong.
All these are incidental aspects of his having assumed this new identity in coming to America, and not some separate independent fraud that has no relationship.

If he committed other frauds, of tax fraud, for example, then he would be deportable on those independently, and so we're not talking about a denial of a waiver in those cases, but the fact that he's deportable on some other ground.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you're saying, as you've said before during your argument, that he can repeat the same fraud unendingly and there are no consequences to it.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: And that's the purpose--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the Attorney General must grant a waiver.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Unless there are other adverse factors, other than that statement, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Just repeating the fraud is not sufficient.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's our position, Your Honor, the same fact.
The purpose of the waiver is not to relieve Mr. Yang of any obligations.
He could still be prosecuted criminally.
His citizenship was denied.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you comment on... go back to sort of a basic point of the... the statute in... before its most recent amendment said that the provisions of 241 and so forth and so on shall not apply to an alien otherwise admissible.
Now it says with respect to those, the Attorney General may, in her discretion, waive.
How do you get around the fact that one was a mandatory waiver and the other is a discretionary waiver?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: At the time there was a mandatory waiver of deportation.

There is also a discretionary waiver for exclusion, and the Immigration Service's interpretation or application of the discretionary waiver was also to disregard the fraud that renders him inadmissible in deciding discretion, so that's the stage that was set when Congress in 1981 passed the new legislation to add on the word discretion for the deportation waiver.
It conforms--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And to take out the words, "shall not apply".

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Correct, to make it discretionary, but nevertheless, that did not change Congress' understanding as to the interpretation, the proper application of the statute, because the Immigration Service had consistently in the Alonzo case in 1979, cited in our brief, where the Immigration Service said, yes, frauds--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So the change meant absolutely nothing, in your view.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --Relative to the initial fraud, correct.

It would permit the Attorney General to look at other factors, and we see from the discussion this morning that there are other factors that should render an alien inadmissible... excuse me, that should result in the waiver being denied, even though it does not render the alien deportable and inadmissible.
So there are acts which don't amount to a deportable act, but which nevertheless I think we are agreed are reprehensible acts and should be punished with the waiver being denied.
But in this particular case, we have to focus on the family.
The waiver was for the purpose, was designed for the purpose of preserving families.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What you're saying is that under the old statute reprehensible acts that were not sufficiently serious to be an independent ground of deportation could not be taken into consideration.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That they may now be taken into consideration.
That, you say, is the--

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --is the change.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: And there are some acts that are so reprehensible that even before the 1981 amendment to make it discretionary--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: --we see that persons who assisted in Nazi persecution or engaged in genocide were not permitted to apply for the waiver, and that was before it was made discretionary, so there were people who covered up their past involvement and came to the United States after World War II, and these people certainly should be thrown out of the country, but because the fraud was being forgiven, the INS had no way to deport those people.
They had the relatives, and the waiver had to be granted.
So Congress in 1978 added on paragraph (4)(D) relating to genocide and said those people, they do such terrible things, they don't even get a chance to talk about a waiver.
Other people on the other hand, U.S. citizens' parents, children, spouses, they have a chance to ask that their loved ones be forgiven so that they may stay in this country, and that's the focus.
It's not to reward bad acts, but to preserve family ties, to consider the feelings of U.S. citizens, and not the alien who committed the fraud.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But I think your opponent agrees that there was... there would have been discretion to decide the case the other way, take into... give a greater weight to the family ties and all the rest.
Am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: Well, in the determination of discretion the depth of the family ties certainly would be a factor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In other words, the Attorney... the Immigration Service could have said, well, I think there were two separate frauds.
The 4-year-later business relating to citizenship, I'll treat that as separate.
Nevertheless, I think these family ties are so strong, and he's such a successful businessman and all these other things, I'm going to grant the waiver.
They could have granted the waiver even if there are two separate frauds.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: howard_hom
turn.label: Mr. Howard Hom
turn.text: That's correct.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Hom.
Ms. Brinkmann, you have 3 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
There are two points I'd like to make.
One goes to the separation of these frauds.
It's clear these are separate frauds because they're false statements made for... to obtain different types of benefits, certainly for naturalization.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let me just interrupt if I may.
Isn't it also true you'd take the same position even if they were the same fraud?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.
I just wanted to respond to Justice Ginsburg's concern about the possible criminal prosecution.
It's clear that... well, depending on the actual facts that haven't been fully investigated, that they would have to be for a criminal prosecution.
There are at least three provisions in title 18 that could give rise to criminal prosecution.

1001 for false statements to a U.S. agency, also 1015 having to do with fraud concerning naturalization, and then 1028 has to do with fraud related to identification documents, and depending on the scope of respondent's participation in the purchase of the fraudulent passport and birth certificate, that could also apply.
And in sentencing, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Some of those would also apply to the original fraud in obtaining entry in the first place, right?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --That's Your... correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So it doesn't prove anything.
You acknowledge that that's waivable.
The later one may be, too.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: But there's certainly factors that can be taken into account by the Attorney General.
It's not that the Attorney General has to prosecute and imprison people rather than deporting them.
Certainly if they can be taken into account, for example, in sentencing simply uncharged counts can also be taken into account under this waiver provision.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When the Attorney General forgets about this initial fraud as the policy is, he doesn't then prosecute it criminally, I assume.
He both allows the application under this provision and chooses not to prosecute, I take it.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: I can't speak to that, Your Honor.
I'm not aware of all instances.
The other point I wanted to make had to do with the textual question about otherwise admissible.
The... that term goes to other categories of people that are set forth in section 212 in 1182 as it's codified, of grounds of inadmissibility, excludability.

That has to do with categories that are related to health, to criminal history, stow-aways, smugglers, national security reasons, those are all reasons that statutorily an alien could be inadmissible, and that is what gives meaning to those words, otherwise admissible, in the statute.
Thank you.
Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Brinkmann.
The case is submitted.
